profile.name: Yeray
profile.title: Developer at otogami.com
profile.description:
*   Seasoned developer currently working on iOS, Android, and Raspberry Pi applications. Currently programming in these languages: C#, Dart, JavaScript, Kotlin, Python, and Swift. Co-author of _iOS Apprentice, 8th Edition_ and author/presenter of the _Beginning ARKit_ video tutorial series.
*   Mobile technology consultant with experience helping enterprises manage their communications technologies, particularly data networking and mobile devices.
*   Trusted technical evangelist with a strong track record of community building.
*   Dynamic speaker and presenter, comfortable in front of an audience, a camera, or a microphone.
*   Rock accordion/keyboard player with stage, studio, and live television experience.

details.name: Canadian Business: How to have a great relationship with your IT department
details.description:
_Canadian Business_ magazine has a regular “How-To” section that features advice from a expert, and in the July 2015 issue, _I_ was the expert!

Here’s how they introduced me: Joey deVilla, platform evangelist at GSG Telco, shares four tips for how to keep your tech people from phoning it in. A little acknowledgement really helps.

image.alt: Canadian Business: How to have a great relationship with your IT department

details.name: GSG's Mobility 101: Telecom Expense Management, or TEM
details.description:
"Mobility 101" is a series of videos that I put together for [GSG](http://gsgtelco.com) to help the company's partners and their customers understand various aspects of mobile devices, services, applications, and management.

This was my second video for GSG. This one introduces TEM — telecom expense management — in an entertaining way. As with most of these videos, I’m the “army of one” behind it.

image.alt: GSG's Mobility 101: Telecom Expense Management, or TEM

details.name: GSG's Mobility 101: Intro to MMS
details.description:
"Mobility 101" is a series of videos that I put together for [GSG](http://gsgtelco.com) to help the company's partners and their customers understand various aspects of mobile devices, services, applications, and management.

This 8-minute, 19-second video was my first video for GSG. This one explains what MMS is — it’s short for managed mobility services or mobility managed services, depending on whom you ask. As with most of these videos, I’m the “army of one” behind it.

details.name: Taking Ford Canada’s C-MAX Holiday Challenge (2012)
details.description:
During the 20102 holiday season, I took a day off from my CTO duties at Comprehensive Technology Solutions/Top Right Corner to participate in the Ford C-MAX Holiday Challenge, where we tried to get maximum efficiency out of Ford's new hybrid vehicles and go toy shopping for charity.

(“Top Right Corner” was a name we were considering to replace “Comprehensive Technology Solutions”, but we never went through with the change.)

image.alt: Taking Ford Canada’s C-MAX Holiday Challenge (2012)

details.name: Windows Phone 7 Showcase in Toronto
details.description:
This video shows the highlights from Microsoft’s Windows Phone 7 Showcase, held one evening in Toronto in September 2010. We put the spotlight on Windows Phone apps created by a number of Toronto-area developers including:

*   Mark Arteaga of Redbit Develeopment
*   Barranger Ridler of 4MK Mobile
*   Alexey Adamsky and Alex Yakobovich of Ryerson University's Digital Media Zone
*   Shawn Konopinsky of Nascent Digital
*   Mike Kasprzak of Sykhronics

I hosted and helped organize this event.

details.name: HTML5 and RIAs: Friends with Benefits
details.description:
When I was a Developer Evangelist at Microsoft, a fellow Microsoftie had a problem: he was buried in work and needed a video comparing HTML with rich internet applications (RIAs) such as Adobe Flash or Microsoft Silverlight. “Can you make one…by tomorrow evening?” he asked. “That’s when I have to show it to this group in Montreal.”

I got to work, and the result is this 5-minute, 46-second piece that summarizes the web world in the summer of 2010. I wrote, designed, narrated, and as the credits say, hastily produced this video, and my coworker was able to present it the following evening.

image.alt: HTML5 and RIAs: Friends with Benefits

details.name: Developer Jr., episode 2: Making movies with Windows Movie Maker
details.description:
Developer Jr. was an all-too-short-lived video series for children ages 7 through 12 that aimed to teach them programming and other creative things they can do with computers and technology. It starred me playing myself, and "Junior", an impish puppet played by Brian Hogg. It was sponsored by Microsoft Canada and produced by Butterscotch.com in early 2010.

In this episode, Junior and I make a simple movie using Windows Movie Maker.

image.alt: Developer Jr., episode 2: Making movies with Windows Movie Maker

details.name: “Byte Club” covers b5media
details.description:
Byte Club was a series of videos that covered the Toronto tech scene around 2008 and 2009. As a community leader in that scene, I showed up in a number of these videos.

This was the first Byte Club episode, which covered b5media and featured interviews with the people who ran it, including Yours Truly.

details.name: When to use lambda, when to use Proc.new?
Python: What OS am I running on?
“Byte Club” covers RubyFringe
details.description:
Byte Club was a series of videos that covered the Toronto tech scene around 2008 and 2009. As a community leader in that scene, I showed up in a number of these videos.

This Byte Club episode featured the RubyFringe conference, a very offbeat conference that featured some of the bright lights of the Ruby community, including Obie Fernandez, Zed Shaw, Dan Grigsby, Hampton Catlin, Pete Forde, and Yours Truly!

details.name: Performing
details.description: Upon seeing my accordion, RailsConf 2007 organizer Chad Fowler invited me to come up with a number that we could both perform at the keynote — me on accordion, him on ukulele. Here’s the result: a parody of Radiohead’s “Creep”, re-done as a tribute to Rails creator David Heinemeier Hansson and the “Depot” Rails tutorial.

image.alt: Performing at the RailsConf 2007 evening keynote

details.name: Cited in the book “Hacktivism and Cyberwars: Rebels with a Cause?” by Tim Jordan and Paul A. Taylor (2004)
details.description: Paul Baranowski and I appear for a number of pages starting at page 102 in a section that covers the _Peekabooty_ application.

image.alt: Cited in the book “Hacktivism and Cyberwars: Rebels with a Cause?” by Tim Jordan and Paul A. Taylor (2004)
